qas.question: How did the federal agencies differ from their English counter-parts?

answers.text: no plenary reception statute at the federal level that continued the common law

qas.question: What did the missing plenary reception do?

answers.text: granted federal courts the power to formulate legal precedent

qas.question: Where do the federal courts fall?
Where is judicial power found in the original Constitution?
What does Article Three give federal agencies?

answers.text: implied judicial power of common law courts to formulate persuasive precedent

qas.question: Federal courts are outside of the jurisdiction of what federal acts?
What power did the Founding Fathers remove in Article Three?
Who did the Supreme Court grant judicial power to?
Where is the plenary reception statute found in the Constitution?

plausible_answers.text: at the time the Constitution was ratified

qas.question: When did scholars begin to argue that judicial power includes precedential effect?

context: Unlike the situation with the states, there is <a0_0>no plenary reception statute at the federal level that continued the common law<a0_0/> and thereby <a1_0>granted federal courts the power to formulate legal precedent<a1_0/> like their English predecessors. Federal courts are solely creatures of the federal Constitution and <a2_0>the federal <b5_0>Judiciary<b5_0/> Acts<a2_0/>. However, it is universally accepted that <b7_0>the Founding Fathers<b7_0/> of the United States, by vesting "<b6_0>judicial power<b6_0/>" into the Supreme Court and the inferior federal courts in <a3_0><b8_0>Article Three<b8_0/><a3_0/> of the United States Constitution, thereby vested in them the <a4_0>implied judicial power of common law courts to formulate persuasive precedent<a4_0/>; this power was widely accepted, understood, and recognized by the Founding Fathers <b9_0>at the time the Constitution was ratified<b9_0/>. Several legal scholars have argued that the federal judicial power to decide "cases or controversies" necessarily includes the power to decide the precedential effect of those cases and controversies.
